explanations.A: Looking at the graph we can see point V is located at (0,0) and point W is located at (8,5). This means we need to move 8 to the right and 5 up to travel from point V to W. As we are told the points are equally spaced along the line, we would also need to move 8 right and 5 up to travel from W to X and from X to Y. Therefore, the coordinates of point X are (16,10) which means the coordinates of point Y will be (24,15).
explanations.B: Not quite, (16,10) are the coordinates of X. We are being asked to find the coordinates of Y.
explanations.C: Not quite, this is the midpoint of V and W. Starting at V, how far right and up will you need to move to get to W? Repeat this movement to move from W to X and then X to Y.
explanations.D: Not quite, (32,20) are the coordinates of Z. We are being asked to find the coordinates of Y.

explanations.A: The lowest point has a height of 3 and the highest point has a height of 9. Therefore the height of the triangle is 6 (9-3).
explanations.B: Not quite, I think you have found the width of the triangle rather than the height. Remember it is the y coordinate, the second number, that tells us the height of each point.

explanations.A: Almost! This is the vertical movement needed to get from A to C. We are being asked for the y coordinate of C. How high up is point A? How high up will point C be if it is 24 higher than point A?
explanations.B: Not quite. I think you saw that the horizontal movement from A to C was 7 more than the horizontal movement from A to B, so made this true for the vertical movement as well. Remember, these movements produce similar triangles. How many times longer is the horizontal movement from A to C than A to B? This should hold for the vertical movement as well.
explanations.C: Not quite. I think you saw that the horizontal movement from A to C was 7 more than the horizontal movement from A to B, so made this true for the vertical movement as well. Remember, these movements produce similar triangles. How many times longer is the horizontal movement from A to C than A to B? This should hold for the vertical movement as well. Also, notice that point A has a y coordinate of 3 NOT 0.
explanations.D: Drawing in the horizontal and vertical movements from point A to point B, gives us a right-angled triangle with a base of 1 and height of 3. Doing the same between the points A and C, gives us a right-angled triangle of base 8 and a height that we need to find. We know that the lines AB and AC have the same slope, which means the two right-angled triangles are similar and their sides are in the same proportion. 3/1 is the same as 24/8. Therefore the vertical height between A and C must be 24. Starting at 3 (point A) and going up 24 gets us to 27. Therefore the y coordinate of point C is 27.

explanations.A: Not quite. As the slope of the line connecting (1, 4) to (2.5, 10) is the same as the slope of the line connecting (2.5, 10) and (6, 24) we know the points lie on the same straight line. Remember, two line segments will have the same slope if the right angled triangles, showing horizontal and vertical movements between points, are similar.
explanations.B: Not quite. As the slope of the line connecting (1, 4) to (2.5, 7) is the same as the slope of the line connecting (2.5, 7) and (6, 14) we know the points lie on the same straight line. Remember, two line segments will have the same slope if the right angled triangles, showing horizontal and vertical movements between points, are similar.
explanations.C: To get from (1, 4) to (2.5, 10) we move 1.5 across and 6 up. To get from (2.5, 10) to (6, 16) we move 3.5 across and 6 up. As 6/1.5 does not equal 6/3.5 we know that the two line segments connecting the points have different slopes and therefore cannot lie on the same straight line.
explanations.D: Not quite. As the slope of the line connecting (1, 4) to (2.5, 5.5) is the same as the slope of the line connecting (2.5, 5.5) and (6, 9) we know the points lie on the same straight line. Remember, two line segments will have the same slope if the right angled triangles, showing horizontal and vertical movements between points, are similar.
